title: Fresh Test 1
Fix TaskTable epic grouping and hierarchical ID sorting
description:
Two issues with TaskTable when displaying hierarchical task IDs (e.g., jat-mdyo.1, jat-mdyo.2):

1. **Sorting bug**: Child tasks sort alphabetically instead of numerically
   - Current: jat-mdyo.1, jat-mdyo.10, jat-mdyo.11, jat-mdyo.2, jat-mdyo.3...
   - Expected: jat-mdyo.1, jat-mdyo.2, jat-mdyo.3... jat-mdyo.10, jat-mdyo.11...
   - Fix: Parse the numeric suffix and sort by that number

2. **Grouping UX issues**:
   - Epic with multiple children â†’ show collapsible group, children sorted numerically inside âœ“
   - Standalone task (no parent) â†’ single row, NO collapsible wrapper
   - Epic with 0 children â†’ single row, NO collapsible wrapper  
   - Currently: single tasks get their own collapsible group with just themselves as child = redundant

Implementation:
- Update TaskTable sorting to handle hierarchical IDs numerically
- Update grouping logic: only create collapsible group if epic has 2+ children
- Standalone tasks and empty epics render as regular rows

title: Create gemini-compose multi-image composition tool
description:
Create the gemini-compose bash tool for combining multiple images:

File: /home/jw/code/jat/media/gemini-compose

Usage: gemini-compose IMAGE1 IMAGE2 [...] "INSTRUCTION" [options]

Options:
- --output PATH: Output file (default: auto-generated)
- --model MODEL: Model to use (default: gemini-2.5-flash-image)
- --help, -h: Show help

Features:
- Accept 2-14 input images
- Detect files vs instruction (files exist on disk, instruction doesn't)
- Build parts array with instruction first, then all images
- Encode each image to base64 with correct MIME type
- Default output to /tmp/gemini-compose-TIMESTAMP.png

Examples:
- gemini-compose bg.png person.png "Place person on background"
- gemini-compose style.jpg photo.jpg "Apply art style" --output styled.png

Acceptance criteria:
- [ ] Tool is executable
- [ ] Sources gemini-lib.sh
- [ ] Validates at least 2 images provided
- [ ] Rejects more than 14 images
- [ ] Encodes all images correctly
- [ ] Builds proper multi-part payload
- [ ] Saves composed image to output path

title: Implement clickable activity history in AgentCard
description:
Add click handler to activity history items in AgentCard component to open TaskDetailDrawer.

**Changes to src/lib/components/agents/AgentCard.svelte:**

1. Add `ontaskclick` prop to component props
2. Implement `extractTaskId(preview)` function:
   - Regex: /\[([a-z0-9_-]+-[a-z0-9]{3})\]/i
   - Extract task ID from activity preview text (e.g., "[jat-abc] Starting...")
   - Return null if no match

3. Implement `handleActivityClick(activity)` function:
   - Extract task ID from activity.preview
   - Call ontaskclick(taskId) if task ID exists

4. Update activity items (lines ~1105-1116):
   - Add conditional click handler: onclick={() => taskId && handleActivityClick(activity)}
   - Visual distinction:
     * Clickable (has task ID): hover:bg-primary/10 cursor-pointer
     * Non-clickable (no task ID): hover:bg-base-300 cursor-help
   - Add transition-colors for smooth hover effect

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- extractTaskId() correctly parses task IDs from activity previews
- Activities with task IDs show blue hover effect and pointer cursor
- Activities without task IDs show gray hover effect and help cursor
- Click handler only fires for activities with valid task IDs
- ontaskclick prop is properly typed and documented

title: task detail drawer launch/spawn bug
Fix /api/agents simple mode to respect project filter
description:
The /api/agents endpoint in simple mode (no ?full=true) doesn't respect the ?project parameter.

**File**: dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/+server.js:22

**Issue**: Line 22 calls getAgents() without project filter:
```javascript
const agents = getAgents();  // Should be: getAgents(projectFilter)
```

**Impact**: Returns agents from all projects even when ?project=X is specified in simple mode.

**Fix**: 
```javascript
const projectFilter = url.searchParams.get('project');
const agents = getAgents(projectFilter);
```

**Test**: Verify ?project=chimaro returns only chimaro agents in both simple and full modes.

Found during jat-qzq audit.

title: Add options section with toggles (grid, smooth, color mode, animation)
description:
Implement options section in expanded panel with checkbox toggles for various sparkline settings.

1. Show grid - Toggle grid lines on/off (existing showGrid prop)
2. Smooth curves - Toggle bezier curve smoothing (new smoothCurves state)
3. Color mode - Toggle between usage-based colors and static color
   - Options: 'Usage' (threshold-based) or 'Static' (single color)
4. Enable animations - Toggle transitions on/off

UI Layout:
- Section label: 'Options' (text-xs font-semibold mb-1.5)
- Each option: label + checkbox (DaisyUI checkbox-xs)
- Layout: Stacked rows with label cursor-pointer py-1
- Label text on left, checkbox on right (justify-between)

State Management:
- showGrid (existing boolean)
- smoothCurves (new boolean, default: true)
- colorMode (existing: 'usage' | 'static')
- enableAnimations (new boolean, default: true)

Implementation Details:
- Use DaisyUI label and checkbox components
- Bind checkboxes to state variables
- Apply settings immediately (reactive)
- Color mode could be radio buttons or toggle switch
- Store preferences in localStorage (optional enhancement)

Acceptance Criteria:
- All 4 options toggleable with immediate effect
- Grid lines show/hide when toggled
- Smooth curves toggle affects path rendering
- Color mode switches between threshold colors and static
- Animation toggle disables/enables transitions
- Clean DaisyUI styling matching rest of panel

title: Build reusable Sparkline Svelte component
description:
Create reusable SVG-based sparkline component for token usage visualization.

Requirements:
- Component: dashboard/src/lib/components/Sparkline.svelte
- Props: data (time-series array), width, height, color scheme
- Render lightweight SVG path (no heavy libraries)
- Responsive to container width
- Show hover tooltip with exact timestamp, tokens, cost
- Color-coded sparkline based on usage level (green/blue/yellow/red)
- Smooth animation on data update

Visual Design:
- Clean minimalist line graph
- Use getUsageColor() for line color (from numberFormat.ts)
- Tooltip shows: timestamp (formatted), tokens (formatted), cost (formatted)
- Subtle grid lines (optional, can be prop)
- Auto-scale Y-axis to data range

Props API:
- data: Array<{ timestamp: string, tokens: number, cost: number }>
- width?: number (default: 100%, responsive)
- height?: number (default: 40px for inline, 60px for system)
- showTooltip?: boolean (default: true)
- showGrid?: boolean (default: false)
- colorMode?: 'usage' | 'static' (usage = color by threshold, static = single color)

Acceptance Criteria:
- Renders sparkline from time-series data
- Hover tooltip shows exact values
- Color-coded based on usage thresholds
- Responsive to container resize
- Smooth transitions when data updates
- Works in both system stats and AgentCard contexts
- Performance: Renders <16ms (60fps)

title: Implement optimistic updates for quick actions
description: Add optimistic UI updates for all quick actions in TaskDetailDrawer. When user clicks action (Mark Complete, Assign To, Change Status/Priority), immediately update the UI display before API call completes. On success: keep optimistic update. On error: rollback to previous state and show toast notification. Use Svelte $state for optimistic updates. Include loading spinners on buttons during API calls. Acceptance: Actions feel instant, rollback on error works, toast notifications show on error.

title: Test drag-drop: Error handling

comments.author: jw
comments.text:
**Task Context:**

Testing drag-drop error handling in the unified Queue/Drop Zone pattern (AgentCard.svelte).

**Error Scenarios to Test:**
1. File reservation conflicts (task files conflict with agent's active reservations)
2. Task dependency blocks (task depends on incomplete tasks)
3. Error state visual feedback (red borders, error messages)
4. Error clearing on drag-leave
5. Drop prevention when errors present

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- File conflicts show detailed pattern messages
- Dependency blocks show blocking task IDs
- Errors display inline (not modals/toasts)
- Visual feedback is clear and immediate
- Drop cursor shows 'not-allowed' on errors

Starting manual browser testing now...

title: Enhance /api/agents to return orchestration data
description:
Update dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/+server.js to optionally return full orchestration data.

**Current Behavior:**
GET /api/agents â†’ simple agent list

**New Behavior (Best Practice):**
GET /api/agents â†’ simple agent list (backward compatible)
GET /api/agents?full=true â†’ full orchestration data (agents + tasks + reservations + stats)

**Implementation:**
1. Read existing /api/orchestration/+server.js logic
2. Merge into /api/agents/+server.js with conditional based on query param
3. If ?full=true or ?orchestration=true: return full data
4. Otherwise: return simple agent list (current behavior)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
â€¢ GET /api/agents works as before (simple list)
â€¢ GET /api/agents?full=true returns orchestration data
â€¢ All nested routes still work (/api/agents/[name]/inbox, etc.)
â€¢ Code is clean and well-commented
â€¢ Response format matches old /api/orchestration endpoint

**Notes:**
â€¢ Best practice: optional query parameter for expanded data
â€¢ Backward compatible with existing simple usage
â€¢ Consolidates two endpoints into one namespace

title: Enhance /api/agents orchestration with ?usage=true
Document per-agent token tracking feature
description:
Document the per-agent token tracking feature in dashboard/CLAUDE.md.

Documentation sections:
1. Overview
   - What: Per-agent token usage tracking from local JSONL files
   - Why: Visibility into session costs, optimize usage, budget planning
   - Where: AgentCard components, /agents page summary

2. Architecture
   - Data source: ~/.claude/projects/{project}/{session-id}.jsonl
   - Session-agent mapping: .claude/agent-{session_id}.txt
   - Token types tracked: input, cache creation, cache read, output
   - Cost calculation: Claude Sonnet 4.5 pricing

3. API Endpoints
   - GET /api/agents/[name]/usage?range=today|week|all
   - GET /api/agents?usage=true (orchestration)

4. UI Components
   - AgentCard token display (location: after File Locks section)
   - System summary (location: top of /agents page)
   - Color thresholds and warning badges

5. Usage Examples
   - Viewing per-agent usage
   - System-wide summary
   - Filtering by date range
   - Understanding cost breakdown

6. Troubleshooting
   - "No usage data" - no sessions found
   - JSONL parse errors - malformed files
   - High usage warnings - optimization tips
   - Stale data - refresh mechanism

Add to section: ## Token Usage Tracking

Estimated size: ~150 lines markdown
Dependencies: jat-oig (AgentCard), jat-4bx (system summary)

title: Create Beads activity utility for AgentCard simple timeline
description:
Create getAgentActivitiesFromBeads() utility to show simple task list in AgentCard.

- Format: [task-id] Task title
- No status, priority, or metadata inline (keep simple)

**Data Source:**
- Query Beads tasks WHERE assignee = agent_name
- Show tasks in any state (open, in_progress, closed)
- Sort by most recent activity (updated_at or closed_at)
- Return last 10 tasks

**Output Format:**
{
  ts: task.updated_at or task.closed_at,
  preview: '[task-id] Task title',
  content: task.description,
  type: 'task',
  taskId: task.id
}

**File:** dashboard/src/lib/server/beads-activities.js (NEW)
**Lines:** ~50 lines
**No frontend changes needed** - AgentCard already compatible

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Function returns array of activities matching existing format
- Activities sorted newest first
- Limited to last 10 tasks
- Compatible with AgentCard.svelte (no UI changes)

title: Test hover-to-expand sparkline controls across all use cases
description:
Comprehensive testing of new hover-to-expand sparkline controls.

Test Scenarios:

1. Hover Interaction:

   - All controls keyboard accessible

3. Chart Type Switching:
   - All 4 chart types selectable
   - Active type highlighted correctly
   - Icon in compact badge updates
   - Chart renders correctly for each type
   - No console errors on type change

4. Time Range Switching:
   - All standard ranges work (1hr, 24hr, 7d, 30d, all)
   - Data filters correctly for each range
   - Compact badge shows selected range
   - No data loading errors
   - Handles empty data gracefully

5. Custom Range Picker:
   - Custom button shows date picker UI
   - Date validation works (from < to)
   - Apply button updates chart correctly
   - Can switch back to standard ranges
   - Compact badge shows 'Custom' appropriately

6. Options Toggles:
   - Grid toggle shows/hides grid lines
   - Smooth curves toggle affects rendering
   - Color mode switches correctly
   - Animation toggle disables transitions
   - All toggles work independently

7. Visual & UX:
   - Panel positioned correctly (no layout shift)
   - Panel width appropriate (240px min)
   - All text readable and properly sized
   - Icons display correctly
   - DaisyUI theming works (all themes)
   - Responsive behavior on small screens

8. Edge Cases:
   - Rapid hover in/out doesn't break
   - Multiple sparklines on same page work
   - Works with different data sizes
   - Handles missing/null data
   - Parent component props work correctly

9. Accessibility:
   - Screen reader announces controls properly
   - All interactive elements focusable
   - Appropriate ARIA labels present
   - Color contrast meets WCAG standards
   - Keyboard shortcuts don't conflict

10. Performance:
    - No memory leaks on repeated hover
    - Transitions smooth on low-end devices
    - Data filtering performant
    - No unnecessary re-renders

Acceptance Criteria:
- All test scenarios pass
- No console errors or warnings
- Works across major browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari)
- Mobile/touch interactions work
- Matches ClaudeUsageBar UX quality
- Ready for production use

title: Implement @project:name mention expansion in am-send
description:
Add @project:name mention that expands to all agents in specified project.

Implementation:
- Detect --to @project:name pattern in am-send
- Parse project name from mention
- Query: SELECT a.name FROM agents a JOIN projects p ON a.project_id = p.id WHERE p.slug = 'name'
- Reuse expansion logic from @active
- Display: 'Broadcasting to project 'name': [count] agents'
- Error if project not found

Acceptance Criteria:

- Works for any valid project slug
- Shows expanded recipient count
- Clear error if project doesn't exist

Files to modify:

Dependencies: Requires @active implementation pattern

Impact: Project-scoped broadcasts

title: Enhance jat list with TASKS, AGENTS, STATUS, LAST, PATH columns
description:
Add rich columns to jat list output:

**New columns:**
- TASKS: open/total from Beads (.beads/ in project path)
- AGENTS: count of active agents from Agent Mail (am-agents filtered by project)
- STATUS: 'running' if dev server port is in use, '-' otherwise
- LAST: time since last activity (e.g., '2h ago', '1d ago')
- PATH: project path (truncated if needed)

**Implementation:**
- For TASKS: check if .beads/ exists, run bd list --json, count open vs total
- For AGENTS: query am-agents, filter by project path
- For STATUS: check if port is listening (ss or lsof)
- For LAST: most recent of git commit, agent activity, or file modification
- For PATH: show path, maybe truncate long paths

**Example output:**
```
PROJECT      PORT   TASKS    AGENTS  STATUS   LAST     PATH
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
chimaro      3500   52/732   3       running  5m ago   ~/code/chimaro
jat          -      4/28     1       -        2h ago   ~/code/jat
myapp        3600   0/0      -       -        1d ago   ~/code/myapp
```

title: Write tests for tokenUsage.ts utility

title: Update agent commands to use PPID-based session files
description:
Update all agent workflow commands to read session ID from PPID-based files instead of shared file.

Commands to update:
- commands/agent/start.md
- commands/agent/pause.md  
- commands/agent/complete.md
- commands/agent/status.md
- commands/agent/register.md

Current pattern (using Read/Write tools):
1. Read(.claude/current-session-id.txt) â†’ get session_id
2. Write(.claude/agent-{session_id}.txt, agent_name)

New pattern:
1. Read(/tmp/claude-session-${PPID}.txt) â†’ get session_id  
2. Write(.claude/agent-{session_id}.txt, agent_name)

CRITICAL: Must use Read/Write tools (NOT bash command substitution)

Implementation approach:
- Update all commands to reference new path
- Add error handling for missing PPID file
- Keep agent-{session_id}.txt files in .claude/ (don't change that)

Acceptance Criteria:
- All agent commands read from /tmp/claude-session-${PPID}.txt
- Commands work in multi-session scenarios
- Error messages clear if PPID file missing
- Documentation updated with new pattern

Files to modify:

title: Fix session ID race condition in statusline.sh using PPID
description:
Replace shared .claude/current-session-id.txt with PPID-based files to prevent race conditions in multi-session scenarios.

Current problem:
- Multiple Claude Code terminals overwrite shared file
- Causes agents to read wrong session ID
- Results in session file corruption

Solution:
- Write to /tmp/claude-session-${PPID}.txt instead
- Each terminal has unique PPID (parent process ID)
- No conflicts possible

Implementation in .claude/statusline.sh (line 84):
- Change: echo "$session_id" > "$cwd/.claude/current-session-id.txt"
- To: echo "$session_id" > "/tmp/claude-session-${PPID}.txt"

Also update read logic (line 91-93):
- Change: cat "$cwd/.claude/agent-${session_id}.txt"
- To: session_id=$(cat "/tmp/claude-session-${PPID}.txt" 2>/dev/null)

Acceptance Criteria:
- statusline.sh writes to /tmp/claude-session-${PPID}.txt
- statusline.sh reads from PPID-based file
- Multiple terminals work without conflicts
- Backward compatible (handles missing file gracefully)

Files to modify:
- .claude/statusline.sh (lines 84, 91-93)

Testing:
- Open 2-3 Claude Code terminals
- Run /agent:start in each
- Verify each gets correct session ID
- No cross-contamination between terminals

title: Test PPID session isolation across multiple terminals
description:
Verify PPID-based session tracking works correctly with multiple concurrent Claude Code instances.

Test scenarios:

1. Two terminals, different agents:
   - Terminal 1: /agent:start â†’ create AgentA
   - Terminal 2: /agent:start â†’ create AgentB  
   - Verify: Each terminal maintains own agent identity

2. Two terminals, same agent name:
   - Terminal 1: /agent:start AgentA
   - Terminal 2: /agent:start AgentA
   - Verify: Both can work as AgentA without conflict

3. Terminal restart:
   - Terminal 1: /agent:start â†’ create AgentA
   - Close Terminal 1
   - Terminal 1 (new): /agent:start
   - Verify: Old PPID file gone, new session created

4. Rapid switching:
   - Open 3 terminals simultaneously
   - Run /agent:start in each quickly
   - Verify: No race conditions

Acceptance Criteria:
- All test scenarios pass
- No cross-session contamination
- PPID files are process-isolated
- Old files clean up on terminal close
- Statusline shows correct agent per terminal

Tools:
- Use multiple tmux panes or terminal tabs
- Check /tmp/claude-session-* files manually
- Verify agent-*.txt files are separate

title: Add date range filtering to /api/agents endpoint
description:
Extend the /api/agents endpoint to support date range filtering via query params.

New query params:
- from: ISO date string (e.g., 2024-01-01)
- to: ISO date string (e.g., 2024-01-07)
- range: Quick preset (today, yesterday, week, month, all)

Behavior:
- Filter agents by activity within date range
- Include agents who: sent messages, received messages, worked on tasks, or had reservations during the period
- Return agent objects with filtered activity data

Response additions:
- agents[].activityInRange: count of activities in date range
- agents[].lastActiveInRange: timestamp of last activity in range
- meta.dateRange: { from, to } echoed back

Example:
GET /api/agents?from=2024-01-01&to=2024-01-07
Returns agents active during that week with filtered activity

Acceptance criteria:
- Date range params are parsed and validated
- Agents filtered correctly by activity date
- Activity counts reflect only the date range
- Works with existing ?project= filter

- --aspect RATIO: 1:1, 16:9, 9:16, 4:3, 3:4
- --size SIZE: 1K, 2K, 4K
- --help, -h: Show help

Features:
- Parse prompt as first positional arg, output as optional second
- Default output to /tmp/gemini-TIMESTAMP.png
- Build JSON payload with jq for safe escaping
- Support aspect ratio and size in generationConfig

title: Extract shared agent status calculation logic

1. Beads database for in_progress tasks assigned to agent
2. Agent Mail for active file reservations
3. Returns consistent status based on both signals

- Returns task_id if found (from either Beads or reservations)
- Can be sourced by statusline script
- Documented with examples

1. Empty default: Solid border, 'Drop task here' placeholder (gray)
2. Empty + drag-over (valid): Dashed green border, 'âœ“ Drop to assign'
3. Empty + drag-over (conflict): Dashed red border, detailed error message
4. Has tasks default: Normal task list display

title: Add loading and error states for token usage display
description:
Add proper loading and error handling for token usage display in AgentCard.

Scenarios to handle:
1. Loading state:
   - Show skeleton loader while fetching usage data
   - Pulse animation on placeholder elements
   - Show immediately when component mounts

2. Error state:
   - JSONL file parsing errors
   - API timeout
   - Missing session files
   - Display inline error message (not modal)
   - Provide retry button

3. Empty state:
   - No sessions found for agent
   - Display: "No usage data yet"
   - Gray text, no error styling

4. Stale data indicator:
   - If data is >5 minutes old, show refresh icon
   - Click to refetch

Implementation:
- Use Svelte 5 $state for loading/error tracking
- DaisyUI skeleton component for loading
- Inline error display (preserve unified pattern)
- Retry with exponential backoff (3 attempts)

Edge cases:
- Partial JSONL parse failures (show what we have + warning)
- Network errors vs server errors (different messages)
- Concurrent refetch requests (debounce)

Estimated size: ~60 lines
Dependencies: jat-oig (AgentCard display)

title: Add sparkline API endpoint with caching
description:
Create API endpoint to serve time-series sparkline data with in-memory caching.

Requirements:
- Endpoint: GET /api/agents/sparkline
- Query params: ?range=[24h|session]&agent=[agentName]&session=[sessionId]
- Response format: { data: [{ timestamp, tokens, cost }, ...], bucketSize, totalBuckets }
- In-memory cache with 30-second TTL (per combination of params)
- Support both system-wide (all agents) and per-agent filtering

Implementation:
- File: dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/sparkline/+server.js
- Use tokenUsageTimeSeries utility from jat-daw
- Implement simple cache: Map with timestamp-based expiry
- System sparkline: 24h range, 30-min buckets (48 points)
- Agent sparkline: session range, dynamic buckets based on session duration
- Return 200 with data or 500 with error
- Log cache hit/miss for debugging

Performance:
- Cache hit: <5ms response time
- Cache miss: <100ms (first aggregation)
- Memory: ~1-2MB for 24h of cached data

Acceptance Criteria:
- Endpoint returns valid time-series data
- Caching reduces server load (cache hit logs visible)
- Works for system-wide queries (no agent param)
- Works for per-agent queries (with agent or session param)
- 30-second cache expiry working correctly

Create time-series data aggregation utility
description:
Build utility to parse JSONL files and aggregate token usage into time buckets.

Requirements:
- Parse JSONL session files with timestamp filtering
- Group messages into configurable time buckets (30-min for 24h view, session-based for agents)
- Aggregate token usage per bucket (input + cache_creation + cache_read + output)
- Return time-series data structure: [{timestamp, tokens, cost}, ...]
- Support filtering by agent name
- Support date range filtering (last 24h, session-based)

Implementation:
- File: dashboard/src/lib/utils/tokenUsageTimeSeries.ts
- Function: getTokenTimeSeries(options: { range?, agentName?, sessionId?, bucketSize? })
- Handle edge cases: missing timestamps, partial buckets, empty ranges
- Document time bucket strategy (30-min for system, session-based for agents)

Acceptance Criteria:
- Utility can aggregate system-wide usage over 24 hours (48 Ã— 30-min buckets)
- Utility can aggregate per-agent usage for their session duration
- Returns consistent data structure for sparkline rendering
- Performance: <100ms for 24h aggregation
- Unit tests for aggregation logic

title: Fix dependency visualization in TaskTable - show blocker as header above main row
description:
## Problem
Current TaskTable shows blockers as children (indented below), which is confusing - suggests wrong execution order.

## Solution
Show blocker info as a **diminutive header row ABOVE** the blocked task's main row:

```
  â”‚ â”Œâ”€ blocked by: jat-fmns (Create /work...) â† Context header ABOVE
â˜ â”‚ jat-qe75 â”‚ Add Work link...        â”‚ ðŸ”’ â”‚ â† Main row with checkbox
```

## Key Points
1. Main row ALWAYS keeps checkbox (for bulk actions like cancel)
2. Blocker shown ABOVE as diminutive context header
3. Reading order is natural (context first, then task)

## Implementation
1. Add blocker header row BEFORE main row (if has unresolved blockers)
2. Remove old child row logic that shows blockers below
3. Style blocked rows (dimmed, tinted)
4. Update DependencyIndicator badge (simplify - header shows details)

## Files
- TaskTable.svelte (add header row, remove child rows)
- DependencyIndicator.svelte (simplify badge)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Blocked tasks show blocker info ABOVE in diminutive header
- [ ] Main row retains checkbox for bulk actions
- [ ] Old child row (blocker below) is removed
- [ ] Visual styling distinguishes blocked rows

title: Fix TaskDetailDrawer infinite auto-save loop and multi-project update errors
description:
Fixed two critical bugs in TaskDetailDrawer:

1. Infinite auto-save loop: After successful save, originalTask was not being updated, causing the $effect to continuously detect formData !== originalTask and trigger saves. Solution: Update both formData and originalTask to match server response after successful save.

2. Multi-project update errors: PATCH/PUT/DELETE endpoints were running 'bd update' commands from dashboard directory instead of task's project directory. This caused 'no issue found' errors for tasks from other projects (e.g. dirt-oquo). Solution: Add 'cd "${projectPath}" &&' before all bd commands to run them in correct project context.

Files modified:
- dashboard/src/lib/components/TaskDetailDrawer.svelte (lines 235-248)
- dashboard/src/routes/api/tasks/[id]/+server.js (PUT, PATCH, DELETE endpoints)

Test case: Open kanban board, click task from any project, update status - should save once and update UI reactively without refresh.

title: Filter activities by agent (not shared inbox)
description:
Activities should show agent's Beads task history (tasks they worked on), not Agent Mail inbox messages. 

**Current Issue:**
- Uses getAgentActivities() which fetches Agent Mail inbox
- Inbox includes messages from ALL threads agent is on
- Results in duplicate activities across agents on same threads

**Solution:**
- Query Beads for tasks WHERE assignee = agent_name  
- Show task transitions (open â†’ in_progress â†’ closed)
- Include task ID, title, status changes, timestamps
- Proper agent-specific activity timeline

**Data Source:** Beads .beads/*.json task files, filter by assignee
**Location:** Backend API /api/agents route, replace activities field logic

title: Investigate bd CLI slowness - 5 seconds per command
description:
Every bd command takes ~5 seconds even though raw SQLite queries take 0.003 seconds.

**Symptoms:**
- bd update takes 5 seconds
- bd show takes 5 seconds  
- Raw sqlite3 query takes 0.003 seconds

**Impact:**
- Dashboard bulk operations timeout
- Slow UX for all bd operations

**Investigation areas:**
1. Startup overhead
2. Database scanning for multiple projects
3. Multiple database warning computation
4. JSON serialization

title: Add TTL support to messages schema
description:
Add expires_ts column to messages table for broadcast expiration.

Implementation:
- ALTER TABLE messages ADD COLUMN expires_ts TEXT DEFAULT NULL
- Update am-inbox to filter: WHERE (m.expires_ts IS NULL OR datetime('now') < datetime(m.expires_ts))
- NULL = never expires (backward compatible with existing messages)
- Non-NULL = broadcast disappears after expiry

Acceptance Criteria:
- expires_ts column added to messages table
- am-inbox filters expired broadcasts
- Existing messages unaffected (NULL expires_ts)
- Schema migration tested

Files to modify:
- mail/schema.sql
- mail/am-inbox

Impact: Foundation for time-bound broadcasts

title: Add tmux mouse configuration to install.sh
description:
When users spawn agent sessions via dashboard 'Open in terminal', mouse scroll shows previous input history (UP arrow behavior) instead of scrolling through output. This is caused by Alacritty's faux scrolling feature.

**Root Cause:** Terminals like Alacritty send arrow keys for mouse wheel in 'alternate screen mode' (which Claude Code TUI uses).

**Solution:** Add 'set -g mouse on' to ~/.tmux.conf via install.sh

**Implementation:**
1. Create scripts/setup-tmux.sh that:
   - Checks if ~/.tmux.conf exists
   - Checks if mouse setting already configured (grep 'set.*mouse')
   - Adds 'set -g mouse on' with JAT comment if not present
2. Add Step 4.5 to install.sh (after statusline setup, before tech stacks)
3. Document that users need Shift+select to copy text in tmux with mouse mode

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Running install.sh adds mouse config to ~/.tmux.conf
- Existing mouse settings are not duplicated
- Dashboard-spawned sessions have proper scroll behavior
- Manual tmux attach also works correctly

title: Fix duplicate agent creation when dashboard spawns task
description:
When launching a task from the dashboard, two agents are created instead of one.

**Problem:**
1. Spawn endpoint creates agent (e.g., DullHill) via am-register
2. Spawn assigns task to that agent via bd update
3. Spawn sends /jat:start task-id to Claude (without agent name)
4. /jat:start sees task-id, creates NEW agent (e.g., DullStream)
5. Result: Two agents, task reassigned to wrong one

**Root Cause:**
In /jat:start STEP 1C, there's no handling for PARAM_TYPE=task-id. It falls through to 'no agent registered' and creates a new agent, ignoring that the task already has an assignee.

**Fix:**
Add check in STEP 1C of commands/jat/start.md:

```
If PARAM_TYPE == 'task-id':
  1. Check task assignee: bd show $TASK_ID --json | jq '.[0].assignee'
  2. If assignee exists AND is in am-agents:
     â†’ REUSE that agent (skip am-register)
     â†’ Write assignee to .claude/agent-{session_id}.txt
  3. If no assignee OR assignee not in am-agents:
     â†’ Create new agent as usual
```

**Files to modify:**
- commands/jat/start.md (STEP 1C section)

**Testing:**
1. Kill existing tmux sessions
2. Click Launch on a task from dashboard
3. Verify only ONE agent is created
4. Verify agent name matches spawn-created agent
5. Verify statusline shows correct agent

title: Wire up activity click event propagation
description:
Connect activity click handler from AgentCard through AgentGrid to agents page to open TaskDetailDrawer.

**Changes Required:**

1. **src/lib/components/agents/AgentGrid.svelte** (~1 line):
   - Add `ontaskclick` to component props
   - Pass it through to AgentCard: `<AgentCard {agent} ondelete={handleDeleteAgent} {ontaskclick} />`

2. **src/routes/agents/+page.svelte** (~1 line):
   - Pass existing `handleTaskClick` function to AgentGrid
   - Update AgentGrid component call: `<AgentGrid {agents} {tasks} {allTasks} {reservations} {sparklineData} onTaskAssign={handleTaskAssign} ontaskclick={handleTaskClick} />`

**How It Works:**
1. User clicks activity with task ID in AgentCard
2. AgentCard calls ontaskclick(taskId)
3. Event bubbles through AgentGrid (pass-through)
4. agents page handleTaskClick() receives event
5. Sets selectedTaskId, drawerMode='view', drawerOpen=true
6. TaskDetailDrawer opens showing the task

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Clicking activity with task ID opens TaskDetailDrawer
- Drawer opens in view mode
- Correct task is displayed
- Existing drawer state management works (can open while drawer is open, updates task)
- No console errors or warnings

description: Create AnimatedDigits.svelte component for DaisyUI countdown-style rolling digit animation. **File:** dashboard/src/lib/components/AnimatedDigits.svelte **Functionality:** - Accept pre-formatted string (e.g., '1.1B', '500M', '50K') - Split into individual characters - Wrap numeric chars with DaisyUI countdown span - Non-numeric chars (., K, M, B) rendered statically - Class passthrough for styling **Props:** - value: string (pre-formatted) - class?: string **Key pattern:** ```svelte {#each characters as char, i (i)} {#if /\d/.test(char)} {char} {:else} {char} {/if} {/each} ``` **Acceptance criteria:** - [ ] Component renders formatted strings with rolling digit animation - [ ] Non-digit characters render statically - [ ] Class prop passes through to container - [ ] Works with Svelte 5 runes syntax

title: Update select-all checkbox logic for grouped tasks
description:
The select-all checkbox in the header needs to work correctly with grouped tasks.

Current behavior:
- allSelected checks sortedTasks.every()
- toggleAll uses sortedTasks.map()

New behavior:
- allSelected should check ALL tasks across ALL groups
- toggleAll should select/deselect ALL visible tasks across groups
- partialSelected should work correctly with grouped data

Implementation:
- Flatten groupedTasks to get all visible tasks for comparison
- Or create a derived 'allVisibleTasks' that flattens the groups

Acceptance criteria:
- Select-all checkbox works correctly
- Partial selection indicator shows correctly
- Bulk actions work with tasks from multiple groups
- Selection persists when groups change (filter/sort)

title: Test task 1: Add loading skeleton to dashboard
Create AnimatedCost component
description:
Create AnimatedCost.svelte component for smooth tween animation on cost displays.

**File:** dashboard/src/lib/components/AnimatedCost.svelte

**Functionality:**
- Accept numeric value and format function
- Use Svelte 5 Tween from svelte/motion
- Smooth count up/down animation with cubicOut easing
- 400ms default duration
- Class passthrough for styling

**Props:**
- value: number (raw cost value)
- format?: (n: number) => string (default: dollar format)
- class?: string
- duration?: number (default: 400)

**Key pattern:**
```svelte
import { Tween } from 'svelte/motion';
import { cubicOut } from 'svelte/easing';

const animatedValue = new Tween(value, { duration, easing: cubicOut });

$effect(() => {
  animatedValue.target = value;
});

const displayValue = $derived(animatedValue.current);
```

**Acceptance criteria:**
- [ ] Component smoothly tweens between values
- [ ] Format function correctly formats interpolated values
- [ ] Class prop passes through to container
- [ ] Works with Svelte 5 runes syntax
- [ ] Handles initial mount without animating from 0

title: Add inline editing for suggested task details

- Visual indicator when task has been edited
- Reset button to clear edits via clearSuggestedTaskEdits()

Acceptance criteria:
- Double-click or edit icon enters edit mode
- Edits persist locally until task is created or cleared
- Edited tasks show 'edited' badge
- Edits are applied when creating tasks via batch action

title: Epic: Suggested Follow-up Tasks UI
description: When an agent completes work, allow it to output a structured payload of suggested follow-up tasks (both human and agent tasks). Dashboard parses this, displays interactive UI where human can select/edit/approve tasks, then sends selections back to agent who creates them in Beads. Replaces the ephemeral [JAT:HUMAN_ACTION] approach with persistent task tracking.

title: Define JAT:SUGGESTED_TASKS marker format
description:
Design the structured marker format for agents to output suggested follow-up tasks. Format should support:
- Multiple tasks in one payload
- Task type: 'human' vs 'agent'
- Title, description, priority fields
- Optional: labels, dependencies, estimated effort
- Must be parseable from terminal output (regex-friendly)

Proposed format:
[JAT:SUGGESTED_TASKS]
{"tasks":[
  {"type":"human","title":"...","description":"...","priority":1},
  {"type":"agent","title":"...","description":"...","priority":2}
]}
[/JAT:SUGGESTED_TASKS]

Update /jat:complete command docs with the new marker spec.

title: Parse SUGGESTED_TASKS markers in SessionCard
description:
Add parsing logic to SessionCard.svelte to detect and parse [JAT:SUGGESTED_TASKS]...[/JAT:SUGGESTED_TASKS] markers from terminal output.

- Create SuggestedTask interface with type, title, description, priority, selected, edited fields
- Add detectedSuggestedTasks derived that parses the JSON payload
- Handle malformed JSON gracefully
- Look in larger output window (~8000 chars) since payload may be substantial
- Track user's selection state and edits locally

title: Send selected tasks back to agent via tmux
description:
When user clicks 'Create Selected Tasks', send the selections back to the agent's terminal.

- Format: [JAT:CREATE_TASKS]{...json payload...}[/JAT:CREATE_TASKS]
- Include: tasks array with type, title, description, priority for each selected task
- Include: parent_task_id so new tasks can be linked as children/related
- Show loading state while sending
- Clear the suggested tasks panel after successful send

title: Agent-side: Handle CREATE_TASKS input and create Beads
description:
Update /jat:complete command to listen for and handle [JAT:CREATE_TASKS] input from dashboard.

When agent receives this input:
1. Parse the JSON payload
2. For each task in the array:
   - Run: bd create "title" --description "desc" --priority N --type task
   - If type='human', add --labels 'human-action' to mark it
   - Capture the created task ID
3. If parent_task_id provided, link new tasks as children or add dependency
4. Output confirmation: 'âœ“ Created N tasks: jat-xxx, jat-yyy, jat-zzz'
5. Continue with normal /jat:complete flow

Handle errors gracefully - if bd create fails, report which task failed and continue with others.

title: Add session log captures with structured summary to task activity timeline
description:
Add session log captures to the task activity timeline in TaskDetailDrawer, with structured summary for agent access.

**Two outputs on capture:**

1. **Full log**: .beads/logs/session-{sessionId}-{taskId}-{timestamp}.log (existing)

2. **Structured summary**: .beads/logs/session-{sessionId}-{taskId}-{timestamp}.json
   ```json
   {
     "taskId": "jat-xyz",
     "agent": "HighDesert",
     "sessionId": "jat-HighDesert",
     "capturedAt": "2025-12-04T17:20:00Z",
     "duration": "45m",
     "filesModified": ["src/foo.ts", "src/bar.ts"],
     "errors": ["TypeError on line 45"],
     "outcome": "completed",
     "gitCommits": ["abc123 feat: Add validation"],
     "fullLogPath": ".beads/logs/session-...-full.log",
     "fullLogLines": 2847
   }
   ```

**Summary extraction (no LLM, pattern-based):**
- Files modified: git diff --name-only HEAD~1
- Duration: first/last timestamp from activity.jsonl
- Errors: grep -i 'error|failed|exception' | head -10
- Outcome: parse [JAT:COMPLETED], [JAT:IDLE] markers
- Git commits: git log --oneline from session start

**Dashboard integration:**
- Activity timeline shows 'Session log captured' event
- Click expands to show summary JSON
- 'View Full Log' button opens scrollable panel

**Agent access:**
- When task reopened, agent can Read the summary JSON (small, fits context)
- If more detail needed, Read full log with --offset --limit
- Summary tells agent what was done without blowing context

title: Add hasActiveFilters logic for conditional filter display
description:
Add logic to determine when to show the Active Filters row.

Default filter values (don't show active filters for these):
- Priorities: Set(['0', '1', '2', '3']) - all selected
- Statuses: Set(['open']) - only open
- Types: Set() - empty (means all)
- Labels: Set() - empty (means none)

Show active filters when ANY of:
- Priorities !== all 4 selected
- Status !== just 'open'
- Types has any selections
- Labels has any selections

Implementation:
1. Add constant for default values
2. Add hasActiveFilters derived state
3. Add activeFilterChips derived array

Acceptance Criteria:
- Active filters row hidden when using defaults
- Active filters row appears when any filter differs
- Each chip has dismiss button
- Removing last non-default filter hides the row

title: Create gemini-edit image editing tool
description:
Create the gemini-edit bash tool for editing existing images:

File: /home/jw/code/jat/media/gemini-edit

Usage: gemini-edit INPUT "INSTRUCTION" [OUTPUT] [options]

Options:
- --model MODEL: Model to use (default: gemini-2.5-flash-image)
- --help, -h: Show help

Features:
- Parse input image path, instruction text, optional output path
- Base64 encode input image using gemini_encode_image
- Detect MIME type using gemini_mime_type
- Build payload with both text instruction and inlineData
- Default output to /tmp/gemini-edit-TIMESTAMP.png

Examples:
- gemini-edit photo.png "Remove the background"
- gemini-edit portrait.jpg "Make it Van Gogh style" art.png

Acceptance criteria:
- [ ] Tool is executable
- [ ] Sources gemini-lib.sh
- [ ] Validates input file exists
- [ ] Encodes image to base64
- [ ] Sends instruction + image to API
- [ ] Saves edited image to output path

title: Fix server crash on hyphenated project names in filter
description:
**Problem:**
Server crashes (exit code 143 - SIGTERM) when filtering by project names containing hyphens.

**Reproducibility:** 100%

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Start dashboard: cd dashboard && npm run dev
2. Make API request: curl 'http://127.0.0.1:5180/api/agents?full=true&project=jomarchy-agent-tools'
3. Result: Server crashes immediately

**Expected Behavior:**
- API returns 9 tasks with IDs starting with 'jomarchy-agent-tools-'
- Server remains running

**Actual Behavior:**
- Server crashes with exit code 143 (SIGTERM)
- No response returned
- Dashboard becomes unavailable

**Root Cause:**
The regex pattern in project filtering correctly extracts 'jomarchy-agent-tools' from task IDs, but when used as projectName filter, causes crash in query execution.

**Affected Code:**
- Backend: /lib/beads.js:157-168 (project filtering logic)
- API Endpoint: /dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/+server.js:50

**Workaround:**
Use simpler project names without hyphens (jat, dirt work fine)

**Impact:**
HIGH - Users cannot filter by projects with hyphens in names. Complete service disruption on filter attempt.

**Fix Needed:**
1. Debug why hyphenated project names cause crash
2. Add error handling to prevent server crashes
3. Test with URL-encoded project names
4. Add comprehensive edge case testing

**Discovered During:**
Task jat-cuj - Comprehensive project filter testing
See: test-results-jat-cuj.md for full test report

title: Add number formatting helpers (formatTokens, formatCost)
description:
Create number formatting utility functions for token and cost display.

File: src/lib/utils/numberFormat.ts

Functions:
1. formatTokens(tokens: number): string
   - < 1,000: "XXX"
   - 1,000 - 999,999: "XXX,XXX" (with commas)
   - 1M+: "X.XX M"
   - Examples: 500 â†’ "500", 50000 â†’ "50,000", 1500000 â†’ "1.50 M"

2. formatCost(cost: number): string
   - Format as USD currency: "$XX.XX"
   - Always 2 decimal places
   - Examples: 0.5 â†’ "$0.50", 15.234 â†’ "$15.23", 1000 â†’ "$1,000.00"

3. getUsageColor(tokens: number, type: 'today' | 'week'): string
   - Returns DaisyUI color class based on thresholds
   - Today: <100K green, 100K-500K yellow, 500K-1M orange, >1M red
   - Week: <500K green, 500K-2M yellow, 2M-5M orange, >5M red
   - Returns: 'success', 'info', 'warning', 'error'

Implementation notes:
- Use Intl.NumberFormat for locale-aware formatting
- Add unit tests for edge cases (0, negatives, very large numbers)

Estimated size: ~80 lines (including tests)
No dependencies

title: Audit agent API endpoints for project-filtering bugs

After global agent name uniqueness change, some endpoints may still filter by project incorrectly. Audit all /api/agents/* endpoints to find similar issues.

Check these endpoints:

- /api/agents/[name] (single agent fetch)
- /api/agents (list all agents)
- Any other agent-related endpoints

For each endpoint:
1. Check if it uses bash commands with project filtering
2. Check if it should query globally vs per-project

4. Create follow-up tasks for any issues found

Deliverable: Comment on this task with audit results

comments.author: jw
comments.text:
# Agent API Endpoints Audit - Complete âœ…

Audited all 7 agent API endpoints for project-filtering bugs and implementation patterns.

## Endpoints Reviewed

1. `/api/agents` (GET) - List agents / orchestration data
2. `/api/agents/[name]` (DELETE) - Delete agent  
3. `/api/agents/[name]/reservations` (GET, DELETE) - View/release reservations
4. `/api/agents/[name]/inbox` (GET) - View inbox
5. `/api/agents/[name]/message` (POST) - Send message
6. `/api/agents/[name]/clear-queue` (POST) - Clear task queue
7. `/api/agents/[name]/unassign-task` (POST) - Unassign task

## Implementation Summary

**JS Functions (via lib/agent-mail.js):**
- âœ… `/api/agents` - Uses `getAgents()`, `getReservations()`, `getTasks()`
- âœ… `/api/agents/[name]/reservations` GET - Uses `getReservations(agentName, null)`
- All JS functions support project filtering via parameters

**Bash Commands:**
- `/api/agents/[name]` DELETE - `am-delete-agent --all-projects`
- `/api/agents/[name]/inbox` - `am-inbox`
- `/api/agents/[name]/message` - `am-send`
- `/api/agents/[name]/clear-queue` - `bd list`
- `/api/agents/[name]/unassign-task` - `bd show`, `bd update`

**Direct SQL:**
- `/api/agents/[name]/reservations` DELETE - Direct SQL UPDATE

## Issues Found & Tasks Created

### ðŸ”´ P0 - Critical

**jat-wc4**: Fix hardcoded jat project path in task management endpoints
- Files: clear-queue/+server.js:30, unassign-task/+server.js:31
- Issue: Hardcoded `cwd: ~/code/jat` breaks multi-project support
- Impact: Task management endpoints only work for jat project

### ðŸŸ¡ P1 - High

**jat-0t2**: Fix /api/agents simple mode to respect project filter
- File: +server.js:22
- Issue: Simple mode calls `getAgents()` without project filter
- Impact: Returns all agents even when ?project=X specified

### ðŸŸ¢ P2 - Medium

**jat-xkr**: Clarify inbox filtering behavior for global agents
- File: inbox/+server.js:27
- Issue: No project filtering (uses bash am-inbox)
- Impact: Need product decision on global vs project-specific inbox

## Findings by Category

### Project Filtering Correctness

| Endpoint | Project Filter | Status |
|----------|---------------|---------|
| /api/agents (full mode) | âœ… Supported | OK |
| /api/agents (simple mode) | âŒ Ignored | BUG (jat-0t2) |
| /api/agents/[name]/reservations GET | âœ… Global (null) | OK (fixed) |
| /api/agents/[name]/inbox | âŒ Not available | Needs decision (jat-xkr) |
| /api/agents/[name]/clear-queue | âŒ Hardcoded jat | BUG (jat-wc4) |
| /api/agents/[name]/unassign-task | âŒ Hardcoded jat | BUG (jat-wc4) |

### Bash vs JS Analysis

**Well-Implemented (JS functions):**
- /api/agents orchestration data - Properly uses JS with project filters
- /api/agents/[name]/reservations GET - Correctly queries globally

**Problematic (Bash commands):**
- Task management endpoints - Hardcoded project path
- Inbox endpoint - No project filter capability

**Acceptable (Bash for agent-specific operations):**
- am-delete-agent --all-projects - Correct (agents are global)
- am-send - Correct (agent-to-agent messaging)

## Recommendations

1. **Immediate (P0)**: Fix hardcoded project paths in task endpoints (jat-wc4)
2. **Short-term (P1)**: Add project filter to simple agent list (jat-0t2)
3. **Planning (P2)**: Decide on inbox filtering strategy (jat-xkr)

## Summary

âœ… **Correctly Implemented**: 4/7 endpoints
âš ï¸ **Issues Found**: 3 bugs (1 P0, 1 P1, 1 design decision)
ðŸ“‹ **Follow-up Tasks Created**: 3 tasks (jat-wc4, jat-0t2, jat-xkr)

The most critical issue is the hardcoded project path in task management endpoints, which completely breaks multi-project functionality.

title: Epic: Reorganize TaskTable action column - agent avatar with dropdown
description:
UI reorganization to make action column more intuitive:

**Current layout:**
- ID column: TaskIdBadge with agent avatar
- Action column: Power/caution icon + dropdown + elapsed time

**New layout:**
- ID column: TaskIdBadge with elapsed time (no agent)
- Action column: Agent avatar (clickable â†’ dropdown with agent actions)

**Rationale:**
- Dropdown actions are agent-related (attach, message, release, kill)
- Clicking agent avatar for agent actions is more intuitive
- Elapsed time is task-related, belongs near task ID
- Less redundancy (agent not shown twice)

**Subtasks:**
1. TaskIdBadge: Add elapsed time, hide agent option
2. TaskActionButton: Show agent avatar instead of power icon
3. TaskTable: Wire up the new component props

title: TaskIdBadge: Add elapsed time display, remove agent avatar option
description:
Modify TaskIdBadge component to:
1. Add optional 'elapsed' prop (same shape as current: {display, color, minutes})
2. When elapsed is provided, show it where the agent avatar currently displays
3. Add 'showAssignee' prop (default true) to control agent avatar visibility
4. Style elapsed time consistently with task ID badge (compact, monospace)

Acceptance criteria:
- elapsed prop displays time with color coding
- showAssignee=false hides the agent avatar
- No visual regressions when props not provided

title: TaskActionButton: Show agent avatar instead of power icon for in-progress tasks
description:
Modify TaskActionButton component to:
1. For in-progress tasks with an agent, show the agent's avatar (circular) instead of power/caution icon
2. Avatar is clickable and opens the same dropdown (Attach, Message, Release, Kill)
3. Use AgentAvatar component or similar circular avatar style
4. Show appropriate fallback (initials or generic icon) if no agent image
5. For open/ready tasks, keep showing the rocket spawn button as before
6. Remove elapsed time display from this component (moved to TaskIdBadge)

Acceptance criteria:

title: Selecting project filter returns 'no tasks found' despite showing task count
description:
When selecting a project from ProjectSelector (e.g., 'dirt (2)'), the page shows 'no tasks found' even though the dropdown indicates 2 tasks exist.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to /agents page
2. Click ProjectSelector dropdown
3. See 'dirt (2)' showing 2 tasks
4. Click on 'dirt (2)'
5. Page shows 'no tasks found'

Expected: Should display 2 dirt tasks
Actual: Shows 'no tasks found'

Possible causes:
- API /api/agents?project=dirt filtering incorrectly
- Frontend not passing project parameter correctly
- Case sensitivity issue (dirt vs Dirt)
- URL parameter encoding issue
- Backend getTasks() filtering logic broken

Related: jat-lnz (project filter state), jat-7g2 (navbar integration)

title: Fix performance: consolidate sparkline polling to parent component
description:
Performance issue: Each AgentCard has its own 30-second sparkline polling interval (line 477). With 5 agents, that's 5 separate API calls every 30 seconds.

Root cause:
- AgentCard.svelte line 477: Each card polls /api/agents/sparkline independently
- agents/+page.svelte line 162: Page also polls sparkline every 30 seconds
- dash/+page.svelte line 129: Dash page also polls

Fix approach:
1. Remove sparkline polling from AgentCard.svelte (lines 471-485)
2. Pass sparkline data as prop from parent (already partially done)
3. Ensure parent page fetches once and distributes to all cards
4. Consider using a shared store for sparkline data

Also fix potential effect loop in agents/+page.svelte lines 167-172:
The drawer close effect may cause unnecessary fetches.

title: Create broadcast usage examples and best practices
description:
Add broadcast examples to CLAUDE.md and documentation.

Create examples showing:
1. Basic broadcast: am-send 'Deploy alert' 'Pause work' --from Bot --to @active --ttl 3600 --ack-required
2. Project-specific: am-send 'Feature ready' 'New API available' --to @project:jat --thread feature-123
3. Urgent all-hands: am-send 'URGENT: System down' 'Incident response' --to @all --importance urgent --ack-required
4. Custom window: am-send 'Standup in 5min' 'Join video call' --to @active --active-window 30
5. Checking broadcasts: am-inbox Agent --unread --hide-acked
6. Acknowledging: am-ack MSG_ID --agent Agent

Best practices to document:
- Use @active for time-sensitive coordination
- Use @all sparingly (can be noisy)
- Set TTL for transient broadcasts
- Use --ack-required for critical notifications
- Combine with thread_id for context

Acceptance Criteria:
- 6+ working examples provided
- Best practices documented
- Added to ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md
- Added to jat/CLAUDE.md

title: Create /api/agents/[name]/usage API endpoint
description:
Create API endpoint: dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/[name]/usage/+server.js

Endpoint: GET /api/agents/{agentName}/usage?range=today|week|all
Returns per-agent token usage with caching (1-minute TTL).

Response structure:
{
  agent: string,
  range: string,
  usage: {
    input_tokens: number,
    cache_creation_input_tokens: number,
    cache_read_input_tokens: number,
    output_tokens: number,
    total_tokens: number,
    cost: number,
    sessionCount: number
  },
  sessions: [{ sessionId, timestamp, tokens, cost }]
}

Implementation:
- Import from lib/utils/tokenUsage.ts
- Handle 404 if agent not found
- Cache results with 1-min TTL
- Error handling for JSONL parse failures

Estimated size: ~50 lines

title: Add spontaneous work detection to /agent:complete
description:
When /agent:complete is run without an existing in_progress task, detect spontaneous work from conversation context and git changes, create a backdated Beads task with proper attribution, then complete it normally.

**Real Example:**
User reports 'jat jat 4 crashed all terminals'. Agent investigates, finds -p flag causes non-interactive mode, fixes cli/jat. No Beads task existed. Running /agent:complete should:
1. Detect work signals: 'I fixed...', 'The fix...', 'Updated cli/jat'
2. See git diff: cli/jat modified
3. Propose: 'Fix jat CLI -p flag causing non-interactive sessions' (type: bug)
4. User confirms â†’ create task â†’ complete normally

**Implementation:**
Add Step 1D after Step 1C in complete.md:
1. Analyze conversation for completed work signals (I added, I fixed, I implemented, etc.)
2. Analyze git state (uncommitted changes, recent commits)
3. Synthesize work summary (title, type, description)
4. Present proposal to user for confirmation
5. If confirmed: create task with bd create, continue normal completion flow

**Pattern:** Same conversation analysis approach as plan.md PART 0, but looking for work-completion signals instead of planning signals.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- No in_progress task + detectable work â†’ proposes backfill task
- No in_progress task + no work detected â†’ clear error message  
- User must confirm before task is created
- After backfill task created, normal completion flow continues

title: Fix hardcoded jat project path in task management endpoints
description:
Task management endpoints hardcode cwd to ~/code/jat, breaking multi-project support.

**Files**:
- dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/[name]/clear-queue/+server.js:30
- dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/[name]/unassign-task/+server.js:31

**Issue**: Both use hardcoded project path:
```javascript
const { stdout } = await execAsync(listCommand, { 
  cwd: process.env.HOME + '/code/jat'  // HARDCODED!
});
```

**Impact**: 
- Only works for jat project
- Cannot manage tasks in chimaro, jomarchy, or other projects
- Breaks multi-project dashboard functionality

**Fix Options**:
1. Accept ?project parameter and map to project directory
2. Use project detection from task ID prefix (e.g., chimaro-abc â†’ ~/code/chimaro)
3. Create projectUtils.getProjectPath(taskId) helper
4. Switch to JS functions instead of bash bd commands

**Affected Endpoints**:
- POST /api/agents/[name]/clear-queue
- POST /api/agents/[name]/unassign-task

**Test**: Verify endpoints work with tasks from multiple projects.

Found during jat-qzq audit.

title: Clarify inbox filtering behavior for global agents
description:
The /api/agents/[name]/inbox endpoint uses bash am-inbox which doesn't support project filtering.

**File**: dashboard/src/routes/api/agents/[name]/inbox/+server.js:27

**Question**: Should agent inbox be:
A) Global (show messages from all projects) - current behavior
B) Project-specific (filter by project parameter)

**Current Implementation**: Uses bash am-inbox which only supports global inbox.

**Options**:
1. Keep global (agents are globally unique, inbox should be too)
2. Add project filter to am-inbox bash tool
3. Switch to JS function (create getInbox() in lib/agent-mail.js)

**Impact**: Affects multi-project agent coordination workflows.

**Decision needed**: Product/architecture decision on intended behavior.

Found during jat-qzq audit.

title: Test clickable activity history feature
description:
Verify clickable activity history feature works end-to-end with real data.

**Testing Checklist:**

1. **Task ID Extraction:**
   - âœ… Activities with format `[jat-abc] ...` are clickable
   - âœ… Activities without task IDs are not clickable
   - âœ… Invalid task ID formats don't break
   - âœ… Multiple projects work (jat, chimaro, jomarchy)

2. **Visual Feedback:**
   - âœ… Clickable items: blue hover (hover:bg-primary/10), pointer cursor
   - âœ… Non-clickable items: gray hover (hover:bg-base-300), help cursor
   - âœ… Smooth transition on hover (transition-colors)
   - âœ… Visual distinction is clear

3. **Click Behavior:**
   - âœ… Click activity with task ID â†’ TaskDetailDrawer opens
   - âœ… Drawer opens in view mode (not edit)
   - âœ… Correct task is displayed (matches clicked activity)
   - âœ… Click different activity â†’ drawer updates to new task
   - âœ… Click while drawer open â†’ smoothly updates

4. **Edge Cases:**
   - âœ… Activity with deleted/closed task â†’ drawer shows error appropriately
   - âœ… Activity from different project â†’ works correctly
   - âœ… Click non-clickable activity â†’ no action, no errors
   - âœ… No console errors or warnings

5. **Integration:**
   - âœ… Works alongside existing TaskQueue click-to-open
   - âœ… Works alongside agent card actions
   - âœ… Drawer state management consistent

**Test Data:**
- Use agents with real inbox messages (RedSun: 7 msgs, KindMoon: 3 msgs)
- Test activities from different task completion events
- Test generic messages without task IDs

**Documentation:**
- Document testing results
- Take screenshots if needed
- Note any issues or improvements

title: Split agent counts: Active (reactive) vs Total (historical)
description:
Update dashboard to show two agent counts with clear semantics:

1. **Active Agents** (reactive, real-time):
   - Count agents with active session files (.claude/agent-*.txt)
   - These are agents currently running in Claude Code sessions
   - Updates in real-time as sessions start/end
   - Display: Green badge, pulsing dot for 'live' indicator

2. **Total Agents** (historical):
   - Count all agents ever registered in Agent Mail DB
   - Represents complete history of all agents
   - Static count, only changes when new agents register
   - Display: Gray/neutral badge

UI placement:
- Header stats area: 'Active: 2 | Total: 47'
- Or: 'Active Agents: 2' with tooltip 'of 47 total registered'

API changes:
- GET /api/agents should return both counts
- activeCount: from session file scan
- totalCount: from Agent Mail DB

Acceptance criteria:
- Both counts display correctly
- Active count updates when sessions change
- Total count reflects all-time registered agents
- Clear visual distinction between the two metrics
